Organizer: Karine & Spruce

=====

Be sure to read the entire event listing before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process. If you RSVP from a mobile device you may not see them - visit the site using a computer so you can answer them.

Your safety and the safety of the group is the most important thing. If you underestimate the demands of the trip; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you may put yourself or others at risk – consider this before you decide to participate.

Hiking safely is about being prepared to respond to an emergency situation or being able to send a night in the woods if you have to. Bring your own stuff and know how to use it.

=====

What we're doing

During this long and challenging 14+ mile winter hike, we are going to visit all of the beautiful and exposed summits along the Franconia Ridge, including 4 official NH48 summits - Lafayette (#5 @ 5,260'), Lincoln (#7 @ 5,089'),  Liberty (#18 @ 4,459') and Flume (#25 @ 4,328') and "unofficial" Little Haystack (4,760'). These peaks are all sharp, rugged and exposed peaks that offer excellent views of the surrounding area, including the Kinsman Ridge across the notch and the Pemigewasset Wilderness. More than 2 miles of the hike will be above treeline, and fully exposed - so this hike will depend on good weather conditions. High winds or poor visibility will cancel this hike or we'll select a less exposed hike instead.

After spotting cars at Lincoln Woods trailhead, we'll begin our hike in Franconia Notch, heading up the Old Bridle Path, across the Franconia Ridge Trail and head down the Osseo trail to the Lincoln Woods trail.

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker.

  • If you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us or want to head off on your own, this isn't the trip for you.
  • Likewise, this trip isn't for you if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you or want us to go on without you. 

Expect winter conditions (see updated list of stuff to bring below) and remember that with limited daylight hours, we may finish in the dark. Full crampons (10-12 point mountaineering crampons) are required for this hike, along with headlamp, snowshoes, face protection (goggles and facemask) and all other equipment you'd bring for a winter day hike.

Guests are not permitted. All participants must be members of the Random Group of Hikers. This allows us to keep track of and communicate with each person who signs up to participate in our events.

Dogs are discouraged on this hike due to the exposed nature of the hike. The ice field that develops below Mt. Lafayette could be treacherous and impassable for dogs. If your dog is experienced in all types of winter conditions and you are confident in their abilities, please contact us by email to discuss.

=====

Trip Summary

On this moderate pace traverse trip, we will climb the Old Bridle Path and Greenleaf trails to Mt. Lafayette, then traverse the entire the Franconia Ridge Trail across all the summits to reach Mt. Flume before descending the Osseo Trail to reach flat walk out to Lincoln Woods.  You will need to be prepared for steep, snow-covered, and icy conditions. We will hike about 14.5 miles and climb over 5,000 feet.  It should take an average hiker about 12 hours to complete this trip - this estimate is adjusted to allow for slower travel during winter (carrying heavier packs) and includes time for changing clothing (to regulate your temperature) and gear (putting on/taking off snow shoes or crampons) along the way. While this area is popular, the 1.8 mile section between Little Haystack and Liberty isn't as well traveled as the other trails in winter, so there is a strong possibility we'll be breaking trail and route finding along this stretch.

This trip is considered ADVANCED because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain. You should be an experienced winter hiker who consistently hikes at or better than book time to participate in this hike.

  • Click here for information about our trip ratings

We have traveled these trails many times, including winter conditions, but also researched this trip using the Appalachian Mountain Club's "White Mountain Guide", a trail map, and the Internet. You should become self-reliant by becoming familiar with the route, terrain, and potential hazards since you are ultimately responsible for your own safety.

Click below for more information about each peak:

  • Lafayette (peakbagger.com)
  • Lincoln (peakbagger.com)
  • Liberty (peakbagger.com)
  • Flume (peakbagger.com)
  • Current trail conditions (TrailsNH.com)

We could alter our plans because of fatigue, weather, and/or other conditions and there is no guarantee that we will complete the entire event as described here (e.g. we might not reach the summit).

=====

Weather

Mountain weather is subject to rapid changes and extreme conditions. The higher we climb the colder, windier, and wetter it will be - we will need to be prepared. Remember, on average it gets 3-4 degrees (Fahrenheit) colder for every 1,000 feet of elevation gain. Wind chill becomes a serious danger at these elevations in winter conditions.

Dangerous weather conditions (high winds or poor visibility) will cancel - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants a day or two before this event. We will assess travel and weather conditions during the hike and make changes to our planned trip as necessary.

  • Click here for the current weather forecast for this trip

=====

Clothing, Gear, Equipment, and Supplies

Below is a list describing the minimum required items to participate in this event. Hiking safely is about being prepared so that you can respond to an emergency situation or spend a night in the woods if you have to.

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or out on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip.

  • Footwear: Waterproof/Insulated winter hiking boots with synthetic or wool socks. Gaiters to keep the snow out of your boots. While we may not need snow shoes on the hike you need to bring them to the trailhead - know how to attach them to your pack in case we do need to bring them along. Traction - 10-12 point mountaineering crampons are required. You may also want to bring microspikes, Hillsound trail crampons (which are not actually crampons) or stabilicers along as well, but they are not sufficient on their own.  Make sure your crampons are the correct type for your boot and adjust them before the trip.
  • Clothing: Dress in synthetics, fleece, and/or wool layers to easily regulate body temperature. Make sure your layers fit comfortably over each other. DO NOT WEAR COTTON - while cotton is a great insulator when it is dry, once wet it doesn't dry easily and conducts heat away from the body.
  • Outerwear: Insulated jacket (e.g. fleece or down). Windproof/waterproof shell (with hood) and pants (e.g. gore-tex). Make sure your outerwear fits comfortably over all of your other clothing. Fleece/wool hat, balaclava or face mask, goggles, neck warmer, and glove liners. Windproof/waterproof over-mittens (e.g. gore-tex).
  • Food and Water: Bring high-energy snacks, food for lunch - pack extra "just in case". Bring enough water to stay properly hydrated during the trip - do not rely on a hydration pack (even an insulated one) because the hose tends to freeze. Use insulated wide-mouth bottles instead (e.g. nalgene). 
  • Shelter: You should always be prepared to spend a night in the woods if you have to. Options include an ultralight tarp, a bivy sack, or an emergency space blanket (which packs small and weighs just ounces).
  • Other Essential Gear: Map and compass - don't just bring them know how to use them. Plastic whistle. Headlamp with two sets of spare batteries (lithium work best in colder temperatures). Personal first aid kit with an emergency space blanket (e.g. mylar). Small pocket knife or multi-purpose tool. Matches or wind-proof lighter and fire starter. Toilet kit (e.g. hand sanitizer, toilet paper and a zip-lock bag to pack out your used personal hygiene items). Sunscreen. Lip balm. Sunglasses. Waterproof cover for your pack.
  • Optional Items: Trekking poles. Camera.

=====

Directions

We'll meet at 7am to spot cars at Lincoln Woods Trailhead (where we'll finish the hike). The meeting spot is the parking lot on the north side of Route 112 (Kancamagus Highway) outside of Lincoln, NH. The entrance is just past the bridge over the Pemigewasset River. According to Google Maps this spot is about 135 miles from Boston and it should take about 2 hours 21 minutes to drive there.

  • Click here for the driving directions

Once you open Google Maps simply change the generic starting point ("Boston, MA") to your own starting point to get customized directions.

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=====

Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
